_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Eye wash stations, valve locations/operations, exhaust fans, ammonia detection, dialout system

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.0 EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1.10 Accidental Release Prevention And Emergency Response Policies

The Washington Fruit, River Road Plant refrigeration system uses pure anhydrous ammonia (a commonly used refrigerant for industrial systems) as the refrigerant. Given the quantity handled, anhydrous ammonia is considered a hazardous substance by EPA. Many of the properties that make ammonia valuable as a refrigerant also requires that precautions and procedures be in place to protect employee and public health and safety during a chemical emergency. It is the policy of Washington Fruit to be in compliance with all applicable federal and state rules and regulations. 

Safety at our facility is inherent on the manner in which anhydrous ammonia is handled. While the design of the facility incorporates a multitude of safety devices, safe handling procedures combined with appropriate training of our personnel are key aspects to maintaining safety at our facility.

We have a written Process Safety Management (PSM) plan that complies with the regulations stipulated by WAC 296-67-017. A crucial component of this plan is the Emergency Action Plan, developed in compliance with the Emergency Response provisions of WAC 296-62-3112. The Emergency Action Plan includes pre-emergency planning and coordinating with outside parties. This enables those who deal with emergencies to have a course of action to effectively deal with unplanned events. 

1.20 Facility Description And Substances Handled

Washington Fruit, River Road Plant is a fruit storage and distribution facility. Storage and distribution requires the use of a refrigeration system to preserve the integrity of the fruits. This refrigeration process uses ammonia as a refrigerant. Access to the facility is restricted to authorized employees, management personnel, and contractors.
The regulated substance handled at this facility is anhydrous ammonia.
The ammonia refrigeration system maximum inventory is 15,500 pounds of anhydrous ammoni

a. There is no standby or makeup inventory kept onsite.

1.40 General Accidental Release Prevention Program And Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Washington Fruit complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable state codes and regulations. The design and construction of this facility was in accordance with published standards, tests or recommended methods of trade, industry or governmental organizations. 

Washington Fruit, River Road's written PSM plan incorporates many policies and procedures to ensure safe operation and maintenance of this facility. Plan elements essential to safe operation of the refrigeration system include employee participation, process hazard information, process hazard analysis, operating procedures, training, contractor safety, pre-startup safety review, mechanical integrity, management of change, hot-work permits, incident investigation, emergency response and planning, and compliance audits. This plan will be reviewed annually and updated as necessary.

Training is provided to ensure that each employee involved in operating a process has been trained in an overview of the process, the operating procedures, and safety considerations. This training uses guidelines developed by the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) and Refrigeration Engineers Technology Association (RETA). Only qualified maintenance personnel operate and interact with the refrigeration system. This minimizes the chances of inadvertent error in operation that could lead to a release of ammonia. Startup, shutdown, and any onstream adjustments are handled by these qualified persons. 

1.50 Five-Year Accident History

This facility is a new construction facility, and therefore has not had any significant release of ammonia at the facility in the past five years.

1.60 Emergency Action Program

Washington Fruit, River Road has a written Emergency Action Plan developed to ensure that precautions and procedures are in place to

protect employee and public health and safety during a chemical emergency. It complies with the provisions of WISHA Emergency Response regulations, WAC 296-62-3112. The Emergency Action Plan includes pre-emergency planning and coordinating with outside parties. This enables those who deal with emergencies to have a course of action to effectively deal with unplanned events. 

The approach in the development of this plan has been to identify the ammonia emergencies most likely to occur at Washington Fruit, River Road and establish precautions and procedures to protect life safety and health during an emergency. The refrigeration process has back-up prevention systems to keep processing malfunctions from becoming ammonia release emergencies. If an emergency does occur, the following response personnel, facilities, and equipment are in place:

Emergency Alarm and Communication System
Safe Rooms, Evacuation Plans, and Assembly Points
Personal Protective Equipment

The role and procedures for obtaining external emergency assistance are established with the Yakima Fire Department, including the Yakima Regional HazMat Team stationed in Yakima. The Emergency Response Plan also includes procedures for notification of any potentially affected neighbors. 

All Washington Fruit, River Road personnel will be trained to fulfill their designated responsibilities in an emergency. 

This plan will be reviewed annually and updated as necessary.

1.70 Planned Changes To Improve Safety

This facility started production operations in 2010. All system components meet design specifications in ANSI/IIAR, equipment, design, and installation of ammonia mechanical refrigerating systems. All pressure vessels are built according to American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME), ASME Boiler and Pressure Vessel Code, pressure vessels. Any upgrades or extensive maintenance work performed in the future will be in compliance with those standards applicable at that time and will also be evaluated

through the management of change element as required by PSM standards.  In addition, all of the recommendations from the PHA will be addressed in a timely manner which will imporove the safety and practice of the River Road facility.
